content:
衛生福利部民國107年7月20日 衛部秘字第1072161286號通知單註銷密等
SELECTION AND APPOINTMENT OF THE MATTIONAL CENTRES
It so happens that there are separate International Centres for Salmonella and Escherichia on the one hand and for Shigella on the other, in widely separated institutions, rather than a single International Centre for all the Enterobacteriaceae in a single institution. This arrangement is by now too deeply entrenched to justify any attempt at radical and sudden changes. This does not mean that it is advisable for the National Salmonella and Shigella Centres in any country also to be located in separate institutions. On the contrary, as a general rule it will be expedient for both National Centres of any particular country to be in a single institution. For reasons that will be elaborated below staffing of these National Centres by bacteriologists experienced in salmonella or shigella work is essential.
Not only is it appropriate, in general, that a single institution rather than two should serve as, or house, both the country's National Salmonella Centre and its National Shigella Centre, but it is also equally desirable that there should be only one officially recognized National Salmonella Centre and only one National Shigella Centre respectively, and not several of each in the country. Of course, this does not mean that only one laboratory should concern itself with salmonella or shigella work; this would obviously be most undesirable in any country other than one of extremely small size and population. a 9 A country with health service in certain stage of development will normally have a number of public health laboratories, conveniently spaced to serve its various urbar and rural population groups, and an essential part of the work of any public health laboratory . is enteric bacteriology. Also, in many countries there will be research or similar institutions (as, for example, universities) in which enteric bacteriology may be intensively studied, and this is, of course, not to be discouraged. However, both efficiency and economy require that only one of these laboratories (either an official health laboratory or a laboratory in a research or similar institution) should be recognized as the Netional Salmonella Centre or the National Shigella Centre. If the International Centres were to maintain relations with many National Centres in each country this would not only involve them in excessive labour, but it would also delay development in that country of the ideal arrangement, whereby a central laboratory with highly specialized staff and facilities is established for work which falls outside the scipe of the local peripheral
(E)et
Xcadena Historici
- 15 -
60
